selected_quotes: The earliest archeological evidence of flour dates 30,000 years ago (Upper Paleolithic) in Europe.
Man laget muligens mel i #Europa allerede for 30.000 år siden: #paleo #diet #fb
Yes, #Paleo people ate flour. Evidence of #starch-based #grain processing from 30,000 yrs ago
Interesting paper on flour grain in the #paleo diet
So there is some evidence we ate plants back in the day?

citation.abstract: European Paleolithic subsistence is assumed to have been largely based on animal protein and fat, whereas evidence for plant consumption is rare. We present evidence of starch grains from various wild plants on the surfaces of grinding tools at the sites of Bilancino II (Italy), Kostenki 16-Uglyanka (Russia), and Pavlov VI (Czech Republic). The samples originate from a variety of geographical and environmental contexts, ranging from northeastern Europe to the central Mediterranean, and dated to the Mid-Upper Paleolithic (Gravettian and Gorodtsovian). The three sites suggest that vegetal food processing, and possibly the production of flour, was a common practice, widespread across Europe from at least ~30,000 y ago. It is likely that high energy content plant foods were available and were used as components of the food economy of these mobile hunter-gatherers.

wikipedia.title: Paleolithic diet
wikipedia.summary: The paleolithic diet (sometimes called the paleo diet, caveman diet or stone-age diet) is a fad diet based on the foods that proponents believe paleolithic humans likely would have eaten, such as meat, nuts, and berries.

news.title: Back to our roots: would humans be better off eating a paleolithic diet?
news.summary: Raw foodists and other campaign groups are eager for us to return to the sort of food our ancient ancestors ate. But how much truth is there in their various claims, and is there any real benefit for us in the 21st century? Continue reading...
